Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to safely managed drinking water
column3: Safely managed drinking water is water from an improved water source which is located on premises, available when needed and free from contamination.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to basic drinking water
column3: Basic drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population that relies on limited drinking water facilities
column3: Limited drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population that relies on unimproved drinking water facilities
column3: An unimproved drinking water source is water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with no access to drinking water
column3: Having no access to drinking water means people rely on surface water: directly from a river, dam, lake, pond, stream, canal or irrigation canal.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to improved drinking water
column3: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to safely managed sanitation
column3: Safely managed sanitation means improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed on-site or transported and treated off-site.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to basic sanitation
column3: Basic sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to limited sanitation facilities
column3: Limited sanitation is improved facilities shared between two or more households.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to unimproved sanitation facilities
column3: Unimproved sanitation is the use of pit latrines without a slab or platform, hanging latrines or bucket latrines.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population practicing open defecation
column3: Open defecation is the disposal of human faeces in fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, beaches and other open spaces or with solid waste.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Share of the population with access to improved sanitation
column3: Improved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) Dat: Number of people with access to safely managed sanitation
column3: Safely managed sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site.

column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Open defecation is the disposal of human faeces in fields, forests, bushes, open bodies of water, beaches and other open spaces or with solid waste.\nImproved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

column3: Number with access to sanitation with off-site wastewater treatment
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Safely managed sanitation is improved facilities which are not shared with other households and where excreta are safely disposed in situ or transported and treated off-site.\nImproved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.

column3: Number with access to basic handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Basic handwashing facilities are facilities on premises with soap and water.

column3: Number with access to limited handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Limited handwashing facilities are facilities on premises without soap and water.

column3: Number with no handwashing facilities
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: No handwashing facility is available on the premises.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Improved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Basic drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time is not more than 30 minutes for a roundtrip.\nImproved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Limited drinking water is water from an improved source, where the collection time exceeds 30 minutes for a roundtrip.\nImproved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: An unimproved drinking water source is water from an unprotected dug well or unprotected spring.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Having no access to drinking water means people rely on surface water: directly from a river, dam, lake, pond, stream, canal or irrigation canal.

column3: Rural access
column10: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Safely managed drinking water is water from an improved water source which is located on premises, available when needed and free from contamination.\nImproved drinking water sources are those that have the potential to deliver safe water. They include piped water, boreholes or tubewells, protected dug wells, protected springs, rainwater, and packaged or delivered water.

column12: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation
column15: Limited sanitation is improved facilities shared between two or more households.\nImproved sanitation facilities are designed to hygienically separate excreta from human contact. They include flush to piped sewer system, septic tanks or pit latrines; ventilated improved pit latrines, composting toilets or pit latrines with slabs.
